title: Ben Godfrey on being tutored by Rio Ferdinand and leading Norwich's survival fight
text:

Ben Godfrey has quickly established himself as one of Norwich’s best young prospects.

Godfrey, 21, was made England under-21s captain last month and was flown to Germany for a beat-the-clock hernia operation to get him ready for this weekend such is his importance to Norwich.

But perhaps what has helped Godfrey on his long journey to the Premier League is his down-to-earth attitude and willingness to learn, especially when advice comes from an England legend.

Norwich centre half Godfrey has been quick to turn to Rio Ferdinand whenever he needs some help or tips on defending.

“In terms of being a centre back, there’s not been a better person to speak to for advice in however many years,” said Godfrey who is represented by Ferdinand’s New Era Global Sports company.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

“Anything he says, goes really. He’s class and he helps me so much. He’s got a lot of time for me. He’s a top guy and it’s good to speak to him.

“I will get my clips together after a game, send them to Rio and he’ll come back and say: ‘to be honest, I’d have done this or this…’ or tell me what I’ve done well.

"I’m always trying to learn and improve and there’s no-one better to give me advice.”

(Image: Steve Reigate)

It is easy to understand why because there are similarities because Godfrey likes to be seen as a ball-playing centre half.

He started life like every kid wanting to be a striker, moved back into midfield and only really came into his own as a defender just over a year ago.

Godfrey comes from York, grew up in a family obsessed by rugby league - his dad Alex played for Hull Kingston Rovers - and went through the lower divisions before a year on loan at Shrewsbury finally got him ready for Norwich.

Last season was an incredible joyride to promotion from the Championship and manager Daniel Farke and sporting director Stuart Webber were determined not to abandon the players who got them into the promised land.

Godfrey said: “It’s been the best year of my life. When the final whistle went against Blackburn last season and we’d won promotion, you knew the next thing you’d be doing was playing in the Premier League and it felt so good.

“You can go up in the Premier League, spend a ridiculous amount of money and still get relegated. You may as well go young, hungry, almost naive in a sense, but that means you don’t have any fear. I believe young and hungry is the way forward.

“We really believe we will stay up. 100 per cent. It’s such a mad league, there’s such a long way to go and that’s why we like it because it can mess with your head and one minute you’re losing, the next you are on a winning run.

"But we’re very confident we can stay up.”

(Image: Getty Images)

That unshakeable belief will come in useful in the next few weeks.

After the incredible high of beating Manchester City at Carrow Road, came three back-to-back defeats with a 5-1 thrashing at home by Aston Villa before the international break.

Godfrey himself has spent the last two weeks undergoing surgery rather than joining up on England under-21 duty.

But, incredibly, he is already back in full training and ready to play on Saturday.

(Image: Steve Reigate)

He said: “I had a little operation, was gutted to miss the England games but I had to get it sorted because it had been inhibiting.

"I went to Germany for it, Dr. Ulrike Muschaweck, she’s well known and I knew I was in good hands. They’ve done everything to get me back for this weekend.

“Being made under-21s captain was such an honour.

"Getting called up to the squad was big, it was nice to have Max (Aarons) and Toddy (Cantwell) as well, then being made captain was nice, it’s a massive achievement and I couldn’t wait to tell my family.

“I do see myself as a leader. I don’t know why.

"I enjoy being captain of the team and, with or without the armband, I’d be the same but it’s such a good feeling to lead out your country.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: England U21 captain Godfrey is vital to the Canaries hopes and refuses to shirk any responsibility at Carrow Road
